text: Privacy Policy

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
chapter_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
chapter_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Fortinets FortiGuard Labs captured a phishing campaign that delivers three fileless malware onto a victims device. Once executed, they are able to control and steal sensitive information from that device to perform other actions according to the control commands from their server.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
chapter_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: In Part I of this analysis, I introduced how these three fileless malware are delivered to the victims device via a phishing campaign, and what mechanism it uses to load, deploy, and execute these fileless malware in the target process.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
chapter_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: In Part II, I will focus on the three malware payloads and elaborate on how they steal sensitive information from the victims device, how they submit data to their C2 server, details about the control commands, as well as what they can perform with those control commands.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
chapter_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Affected platforms: Microsoft Windows Impacted parties: Microsoft Windows Users Impact: Controls victims device and collects sensitive information Severity level: Critical

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Ave Maria is a RAT (Remote Access Trojan), also known as WARZONE RAT. It offers a wide range of features, such as stealing victims sensitive information and remote controlling an infected device, including privilege escalation, remote desktop control, camera capturing, and more.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: It is the first of the three malware (refer to Figure 3.3 of the previous analysis) to be injected into a newly-created aspnet_compiler.exe process on the victims device and then run.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Ave Maria has a configuration block that is RC4 encrypted within its PE structures .bss section. The decryption key and encrypted data are together within the .bss. When the malware starts, it first decrypts the configuration block. Figure 1.1 shows the decrypted data in memory.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 1.1 RC4-decrypted configuration block

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: It not only contains the C2 server (mubbibun.duckdns.org) and port (0x3E7), but also a number of switch flags, such as whether to add itself into the auto-run group, bypass UAC (User Account Control), or bypass Windows Defender.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Once Ave Maria establishes its connection to the C2 server it starts to control the victims device. According to my research, the traffic between its client and the C2 server is RC4 encrypted with a constant encryption key "warzone160".

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Ill explain what the plaintext packet consists of through an instance packet as below.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The first dword 0xE466BB29 is a magic value; each packet must start with this value. The 0xEA70 is the size of the command data. It is 0x0 if no command data. The 0x1E is the command number of this packet. The subsequence data is the command data, which is an executable file in this example packet. It doesnt appear if there is no command data for the command.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Ave Maria provides these features:

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Remote VNC (Virtual Network Computing), Remote Shell, File Explorer, Process Manager, Remote Webcam, Password Manager, Reverse Socks, Download & Execute a file, Remote Keylogger, HRDP Manager as well as Privilege Escalation.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 1.2 Display of Remote Keylogger feature

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 1.2 shows the feature (on the C2 server side) of the online Remote Keylogger (command 24H). You can see here what is recorded when I open a Chrome browser and type in www.fortinet.com and press Enter on a victims device.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Its Password Manager feature aims to steal credentials from a group of apps, listed below, including internet browsers and email clients.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Google Chrome, Epic Privacy browser, Microsoft Edge, UCBrowser, Tencent QQBrowser, Opera, Blisk, Chromium, Brave-Browser, Vivaldi, Comodo Dragon, Torch, Slim, CentBrowser, Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Outlook, Microsoft Messaging, Mozilla Thunderbird, Tencent Foxmail, and more.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 1.3 The pseudo code of stealing credentials

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 1.3 is a screenshot of the pseudo code where Ave Maria steals the credentials (command 20H) from the defined files for several internet browsers. It calls a function to RC4-encrypt the credentials and send them to the C2 server.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Table 1.1 presents most of the control commands that Ave Maria supports.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Table 1.1 Ave Marias Control Commands

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: It collects basic information from the victims device and sends it to the C2 server to register the client in the server. Below is the data of such packet.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 2.2 The registration packet to the C2 server

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The first 64-bit integer 0x62 is the entire packet size. The subsequent data is sealed in a serialized binary object. The 16H data (00 01 0000) is kind of header. The next 0x4a is the size of the following strings, which is a variable length integer. The last 0x0b is a close flag.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Lets take a look the sealed string, which consists of a packet number (654321), client group id (3H4RHL), the victims username and pc name (Bobs@BOBS-PC), the victims location code (US), the system information (Windows 7 Pro), date (05/09/2022), client version (3.1), and whether any antivirus product is being used (False).

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Once the C2 server receives this packet, it shows the victims information in a list, as shown in Figure 2.3, Connected client.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 2.3 - PandoraHVNC RAT C2 server interface and features

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The hacker is then able to control the victims machine by right-clicking the client and clicking the items on the menu. Figure 2.3 also demonstrates the right-click menu and features.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 2.4 The credentials packet to C2 server

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 2.4 is a screenshot of two packets, the first line is the received command control packet with command number 3308. The rest is the packet sent to the C2 server with packet number 3308. This is followed by the stolen credentials from the victim when Pandora Recovery is clicked by the hacker. As mentioned before, the two packets are sealed in the serialized binary object.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Table 2.1 demonstrates the details of all the control commands and features that PandoraHVNC RAT provides.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Table 2.1 - List of control commands of PandoraHVNC RAT

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: BitRat is more powerful than AveMariaRAT and PandoraHVNC because it provides a great number of control commands (172 commands) to control the victims device.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 3.4 shows the dashboard to a connected victim on the C2 server side. On the left is the basic information of the victims device, while there are some features listed on the right.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 3.4 Dashboard and features that BitRat supports

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Other than the features from the dashboard, it also supports the following features from the main context menu:

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Chat Clear browsers Clipboard management DLL injection Change desktop background Open website Notes UAC bypass Kill Windows Defender Show preview of screen or webcam Keylog download & search Reverse socks System management (reboot, shutdown, sleep, etc.) BitRat clients update and uninstall DDoS attack (plugin) Mining (plugin) Telegram bot (plugin) Passwords Logins (plugin) And more

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The second fileless malware injected into RegAsm.exe is PandorahVNC Rat, which is a commercial software. It was developed using C#, a Microsoft .Net framework. It supports features to steal credentials from some popular applications, like Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Firefox, Outlook, Foxmail, and so on. It also supports control commands to control the victims device, such as starting a process, capturing the screenshot, manipulating the victims mouse and keyboard, and more.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: When it starts, it defines the following variables. They are the C2 server address, port, and the group id that will be used when sending data to the C2 server.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: string str = "vncgoga.duckdns.org"; //C2 server string str2 = "1338"; // TCP port string identifier = "3H4RHL"; // Group id

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Next, it proceeds to extract a core module from a base64-encoded string, which performs all features of PandoraHVNC RAT. It then deploys the core module into a newly-created process, cvtres.exe (a file from Microsoft .Net framework), using process hollowing. It tries to find the file from one of the following:

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\" "C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v2.0.50727\

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: If it fails to locate the file, it quits without running PandoraHVNC RATs core module. The C2 server address, port, and group id will be passed to the new process during the process hollowing. Figure 2.1 shows the code segment to perform the process hollowing.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 2.1 Code to perform the process hollowing

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: BitRat has a configuration block encrypted similar to the Ave Maria Rat. Figure 3.1 shows the just decrypted configuration block in memory, where it contains C2 server (maraipasoo[.]duckdns[.]org) & port (890), client ID (f2b8b66873ca913a), and more.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 3.1 Decrypted configuration block

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: It proceeds to connect to the C2 server. It then uses TLS 1.2 protocol plus a cipher suite of RAS+AES 256 to transfer and encrypt its packet. Figure 3.2 shows the model that it uses to encode the plain text data with Base64 and encrypt with AES-256. And finally, it sends the encrypted data to the C2 server over TLS 1.2 protocol.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 3.2 The outline of how a packet is transformed and sent to the C2 server

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Ill take a moment here to explain what the plaintext packet looks like. Figure 3.3, below, is a screenshot of the debugger when BitRat was about to Base64-encode the plaintext packet with the basic information of the victims device.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Figure 3.3 Basic information packet before Base64 encoding

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The packet consists of many parts separated by |, including a client ID (f2b8b66873ca913a), user name, computer name, CPU information, GPU card, system name (Win 7), systems uptime, system idle time, RAM amount, IP address, whether or not the login user is an administrator, BitRat client version (1.38), and so on. Next, the packet goes through Base64-encoding and AES-256 encryption, which is eventually sent to the C2 server.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Once the C2 server receives this packet, the victims device shows up in its control interface, where the hacker is able to control the infected device.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The third fileless malware injected into aspnet_compiler.exe is BitRat, which is said to be a high quality and efficient RAT. It provides information collection like clipboard logger, keylogger, application credentials, Webcam logging, and Voice Recording. It has wide control commands for controlling the victims device, including downloading and executing a file, performing remote desktop control, controlling processes and services, reverse socks, and more.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: While BitRat receives the control command packet, it only needs a AES-256 decryption to restore the plaintext packet. I will explain the structure of a plaintext command packet using the following example:

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: "ddos_start|MTkyLjE2OC4yMi4xNQ==|3333|1|tcp|tcp|1|0|L3NpdGUucGhwP3g9dmFsMSZ5PXZhbDI="

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Every command packet starts with a command name string and subsequent parameters, which are separated by |.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The above example command asks the infected device to start a DDoS attack, where ddos_start is the command name, MTkyLjE2OC4yMi4xNQ== is the Base64-encoded target IP, 3333 is the target port, flood method is tcp, protocol is tcp, thread number is 1, size is 0, and the last field is the data.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: On the very first time, BitRat initializes a linked list with nodes containing a command name and a command number (like ddos_start for 85H) as well as some flags. BitRat has a method to go through these nodes looking for a node that matches the command name from the packet by string comparison. The command name starts at offset +10H of the node and the corresponding command number is saved in a dword at offset +28H. Below is a dumped node of ddos_start.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: BitRat performs the action according to the command number. Table 3.1 lists the most control commands, with brief command descriptions that BitRat supports.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Table 3.1 The most control commands of BitRat

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: In this second part the series, I examined the three fileless malware payloads included in the phishing campaign. I also explained what processes they inject into and execute.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Next, I introduced how these three malware connect to their C2 server and described the structure of the packets sending to the C2 server. I also presented the values in the control command packets sent to the malware clients to control the victims device to perform further malicious tasks.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: I elaborated the features that the three malware provide and used several examples to prove how the attacker uses them. From my research, you also learned the differences between their features.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: I also made three tables to list the control commands with brief descriptions.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: Fortinet customers are already protected from this malware by FortiGuards Web Filtering, AntiVirus, FortiMail, FortiClient, FortiEDR services and CDR (content disarm and reconstruction) feature, as follows:

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: All relevant URLs have been rated as "Malicious Websites" by the FortiGuard Web Filtering service.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The phishing email attached Excel document can be disarmed by the FortiGuard CDR (content disarm and reconstruction) feature.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: The captured Excel sample at the beginning and the downloaded html file as well as the Powershell file with three fileless malware payload files are detected as "VBA/Agent.DDON!tr", "JS/Agent.DDON!tr.dldr" and "PowerShell/Agent.e535!tr" and are blocked by the FortiGuard Antivirus service.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: FortiEDR detects both the Excel file and the huge Powershell file as malicious based on its behavior.

report_title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II
text: In addition to these protections, we suggest that organizations have their end users also go through the FREE NSE training: NSE 1 Information Security Awareness. It includes a module on Internet threats that is designed to help end users learn how to identify and protect themselves from phishing attacks.
